overviews.overview: The part-time MBA/PGDM is a course specially designed for working professionals who cannot take time off work to attend full-time courses. A Part-Time MBA is an internationally recognized degree that helps students develop the skills important for careers in management and business. Having an MBA degree enables one to learn how to successfully manage, lead, organize and adapt in various business environments. Part-Time MBA/PGDM Course Details Because part time MBA classes take place on weekends and after business hours, they are more flexible. MBA Part-Time degrees are great for those who are already employed or looking to improve their skills.

faqs.question: What is a part-time MBA course?
faqs.answer: Part Time MBA is a degree course offered by universities (both private and government) and colleges affiliated with these universities. Postgraduate Diploma in Management (PGDM) is a Diploma programme offered by B-schools that are recognised by the Central government's nodal body for technical education, the All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE). Part Time PGDM and MBA are both business-orientated programmes designed with an aim to equip an individual who aspires to climb up the hierarchy and foray into the management field. In part-time MBA/PGDM students also have the unique opportunity to integrate their learning directly with their day-to-day professional roles. They can get promotions in their existing organisation, in addition to getting lucrative and promising job opportunities.

faqs.question: Why should I pursue part-time MBA course?
faqs.answer: For those wishing to advance their professional possibilities while maintaining their current responsibilities, a part-time MBA (Master of Business Administration) can provide a number of advantages. A part-time MBA has the following major benefits: Flexibility : Part-time MBA programmes are more flexible in terms of classes and learning, hence more convenient. Career Growth : A part-time MBA allows students to continue working while pursuing their degree. Practical Knowledge : An MBA degree helps students gain various management skills essential in the practical day to day working of an organisation. Networking Opportunities : An MBA programme, whether full-time or part-time, provides excellent networking opportunities. The aspirants can connect with fellow students, alumni, professors, and industry professionals, which can be valuable for their career path.

faqs.question: Is Part-time MBA better than full-time MBA?
faqs.answer: Part-time MBA is more affordable and convenient for working professionals. It allows students to imbibe the learnings in a classroom environment which is offered in a pedagogy that is a mix of traditional and modern methods. This mode also enables students to interact with professors, guest lecturers from industries, and fellow students during or after the classes. Part-time MBA can be pursued from several renowned colleges, including the prestigious IIMs, at fees ranging from INR 4 Lacs to 25 lakh. Read More: Popular Colleges for Part-time MBA

faqs.question: What is a Part-Time MBA, and how is it different from a Full-Time MBA?
faqs.answer: A Part-Time MBA is a postgraduate business management programme designed for working professionals who want to pursue an MBA without leaving their current job. Unlike the full-time MBA , which requires the students to attend classes daily for two years. A part-time MBA offers more flexibility with evening, weekend, or online classes which helps the students to balance work and study.

faqs.question: What is the duration of part-time MBA?
faqs.answer: The duration of a Part-time MBA is flexible. Students can complete the programme as per their convenience and capabilities within three to five years. Each institute has its specific duration and some of them also allow students to take an extension to complete the programme. This is the flexibility offered by the institutes to the Part-time MBA students since they are pursuing the programme while continuing with their jobs.

faqs.question: Can I do MBA without giving any entrance exam?
faqs.answer: In rare circumstances, it is possible to pursue an MBA without taking any entrance exam. The CAT, CMAT, MAT, GMAT, XAT , and other standardized entrance exams are needed for admission to many MBA courses worldwide. If you are not planning to take the CAT in 2026, listed below are some direct admission eligibility criteria to help you be accepted into MBA programs . The minimum score required in the UG level examination may differ from one college to another, however, the student need to have scored at least 50%-65% aggregate in his or her graduation. For the reserved category, the score should at least be 45% aggregate. Some institutes accept other competitive exam scores such as XAT, MAT, GMAT, NMAT, ATMA, SNAP, etc. If you did not appear for the CAT exam and still wish to get admission to the best MBA colleges in India without CAT, then, here is a list of top MBA institutes that give admissions based on different entrance criteria or exams. faqs.question: Which is a better option among specialized part-time MBA and a generic one?
faqs.answer: This is a decision that a student should take based on his/her career aspiration or goal. If candidates aims to work in a particular sector, then it is best to choose a suitable specialization. On the other hand, if the student wants to excel in the present job and get the management lessons on each function to prep for a leadership role, then a general Part-time MBA would suffice. Moreover, there are several electives to opt for in a general Part-time MBA programme as well, which a student can choose based on his/her interest areas.

faqs.question: Is full time MBA or part time MBA better for MBA in HR?
faqs.answer: Both the courses are good for an individual who wishes to make a career in this field. Students can read on to know the difference between both the courses: If you want to advance your profession quickly, a full-time MBA in Human Resources is an excellent choice. You will be exposed to the most recent HR concepts and best practises, as well as the opportunity to network with other HR professionals. You will, however, be required to commit to a full-time schedule and pay the increased tuition rates. If you are searching for a more flexible option that will allow you to continue working while earning your degree, an executive MBA in HR is a suitable choice. You will still master the most recent HR principles and best practises, but at your own speed and without having to pay the higher tuition rates. Read More: Difference between MBA and Executive MBA

QA.question: For whom is the part-time MBA best suited?
QA.answer: Part-time MBA is best suited for working professionals, who cannot afford to invest the requisite time and funds required for the full-time Executive MBA . This allows them to attend evening or weekend classes, which would let the students continue with their jobs alongside upgrading their skillsets and adding an 'MBA' tag to their profiles. The need for part-time MBA/PGDM programmes is growing at the moment. The top occupations for part-time MBA/PGDM holders are consulting, senior management, and entrepreneurship. Such applicants are sought after for senior management roles in a variety of industries, including Banking, Operations, Consulting, Insurance, Business Analytics , IT , Marketing, and HR.

QA.question: What can students do after part-time MBA?
QA.answer: If the employee wants to get promoted to a higher managerial post, a Part-time MBA would provide him/her a much-needed push to climb up the corporate ladder . In case he/she wants to change career path or explore a more challenging leadership role in a different industry type or organisation in the same sector, the Part-time MBA would be the roadmap to the new avenue, without having to take a break from the job and suspending the earning . Some may also like to venture into entrepreneurship after the course completion.

QA.question: Who should pursue a Part-Time MBA?
QA.answer: A part-time MBA is ideal for the following set of people: Working professional who wants to enhance their career prospects without taking a break from their work. Entrepreneurs who wish to develop managerial and strategic skills. Mid-level managers who are aiming to transition into senior leadership roles. Professional who want to specialize in specific domain such as marketing, finance, operations or HR while gaining hands on work experience. This format is especially benifting for people who cannot afford to leave their jobs due to financial or personal problems.

questions.question_text: Do MBA students at Manipur Institute of Management Studies have access to external scholarships?

answers.answer_text: Manipur Institute of Management Studies MBA students can apply for external and corporate scholarships alongside university awards. These include bank-funded and trust-based scholarships. Application procedures and deadlines vary by sponsoring organisation.

questions.question_text: What university-sponsored awards are offered to MBA students at Manipur Institute of Management Studies?

answers.answer_text: Manipur Institute of Management Studies offers Gold Medals and Cash Awards for academic excellence. These include memorial gold medals for top MBA performers. Awards are based on first-class results and overall performance.

questions.question_text: Are there any additional charges apart from MBA tuition fees at Manipur Institute of Management Studies?

answers.answer_text: Yes, apart from the MBA tuition fee at Manipur Institute of Management Studies, students may need to pay additional charges such as registration, examination, library, and other university fees. These are usually communicated during admission or counselling.

questions.question_text: What selection process is followed for MBA at Manipur Institute of Management Studies?

answers.answer_text: Applicants qualifying in the entrance test are shortlisted for Group Discussion and Personal Interview. Selection is done purely on merit. Candidates must attend these rounds at their own cost and expense.

questions.question_text: What minimum marks are required for SC/ST candidates for MBA at Manipur Institute of Management Studies?

answers.answer_text: SC/ST candidates applying for MBA at Manipur Institute of Management Studies must secure at least 45% aggregate marks. This relaxation applies only to reserved categories. Final eligibility is subject to university norms.

questions.question_text: Does Manipur Institute of Management Studies conduct counselling for MBA admissions?

answers.answer_text: Yes, counselling for MBA admissions at Manipur Institute of Management Studies is conducted by Manipur University. Seat allotment is based on CUET (PG) scores. Candidates must select MIMS during the counselling process.

questions.question_text: How can candidates apply for MBA at Manipur Institute of Management Studies?

answers.answer_text: Candidates must first appear for CUET (PG) and then register on the Manipur University admission portal. Separate registration on the Samarth portal is required for programme selection. Final admission depends on counselling and seat allotment.

questions.question_text: Is it a good idea to give multiple MBA entrance exams like CAT CMAT XAT MAT?
questions.answer_text: Yes, giving multiple MBA entrance exams like CAT, CMAT, XAT, and MAT is generally a good idea. Most of the syllabus overlaps, so your preparation works across exams, and it reduces the risk of depending on just one test.Different exams open doors to different colleges. For example, CAT is needed for IIMs, while exams like CMAT, MAT, or NMAT are accepted by many private B-schools. Colleges such as Athena School of Management also consider multiple exams and focus on the overall profile, so having more scores gives you flexibility.Overall, multiple exams simply mean more options and backup choices, which is always helpful.

questions.question_text: Is quality of MBA education declining?
questions.answer_text: I don't think the quality of MBA education is declining overall, but it's becoming very uneven. A lot more colleges have opened in the last few years, so the quality really depends on the institute you choose.Top and mid-tier B-schools still maintain good faculty, internships and placement support. But some smaller colleges don't update their curriculum or offer enough industry exposure, which makes the experience feel outdated.So it's not that MBA quality is falling everywhere — it's just important to pick a college that focuses on practical learning, internships and industry linkages rather than just classroom teaching.
